subject: How can I test something that isn't there?
msgSnippet: ... I write the test, then use Eclipse to generate classes, interfaces and method stubs as I go. When the test compiles, I run it to watch it fail. This way I

Subject: How can I test something that isn't there?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=282027414; y=A2zUrEDNgfHRtPlNfyM1OH8HH_H7DimnAW51qWrv323zv8c
X-Yahoo-Profile: nails762

Tracey Annison wrote:

> So I don't see how you can write a test class that has failing tests
> that move over to passing tests as you write the code, (as I see TDD
> asking for) when the thing you're testing doesn't exist yet. I guess
> you could code in all the skeleton of the class, with the methods &
> such (though this won't compile unless you really do return what you
> say you will), then write the tests, then add the rest of the code.
> But I don't see the great advantage of that, to be honest...

I write the test, then use Eclipse to generate classes, interfaces and 
method stubs as I go. When the test compiles, I run it to watch it fail. 
This way I know my test actually tests /something/. Only then do I make 
it pass.

When I do this, I get the opportunity to see my code in black and white 
on the screen. I get to ask myself, "Is the design any good?" or more 
correctly, "Does the design suck in an obvious way?" I'm surprised how 
often it does. :) It's often not until I have to /use/ the API that I 
realize it sucks.

So that's how I do it. I tried writing the skeleton code, then writing 
the test, but I found I couldn't easily enough track in my head the code 
I needed for the test I wanted to write, so I decided to let the test 
pull the code out of me. It works for me.

Take care.
